Anti-Doping Rule Violations (ADRVs) are infractions related to doping that can be committed by athletes or Athlete Support Personnel (ASP).
ADRVs include actions like the presence of a Prohibited Substance, Use of Prohibited Substances or Methods, Evading Sample Collection, Whereabouts Failures, Tampering with Doping Control, and more.
These violations can lead to sanctions and ineligibility in sports governed by the World Anti-Doping Code.
The 'Presence of a Prohibited Substance' occurs when a sample (urine or blood) contains a Prohibited Substance, its Metabolite(s), or Marker(s).
Proof is established through the analysis of sample A, confirmation by sample B, or the second bottle of split sample A.
No intent, Fault, Negligence, or knowing Use needs to be demonstrated for this violation.
The 'Use or Attempted Use of a Prohibited Substance' can be proven by admission, witness statements, documentary evidence, or longitudinal profiling.
Proof of intent is required, but even without intent, the Principle of Strict Liability applies.
Evading Sample Collection means avoiding a Doping Control Official to avoid testing.
Refusing means intentionally not submitting to sample collection after notification without a compelling justification.
Failing to submit means not providing a sample, either intentionally or negligently.
Whereabouts Failures apply to athletes in a Registered Testing Pool (RTP).
A missed test occurs if an athlete is not present at the indicated location.
A filing failure is recorded if the athlete fails to provide or update whereabouts information.
Three missed tests or filing failures in twelve months result in an ADRV.
Tampering with Doping Control involves intentional actions that subvert the Doping Control process.
This includes offering or accepting bribes, preventing sample collection, falsifying documents, and other similar actions.
Possession of a Prohibited Substance or Method involves having such items without a valid reason.
Valid reasons include having a Therapeutic Use Exemption (TUE), prescription from a qualified doctor, or medication for a sick person.
Trafficking or Attempted Trafficking involves selling, giving, or distributing Prohibited Substances or Methods.
This applies to athletes, ASPs, or any person subject to anti-doping authority.
In Kenya, trafficking is also a criminal offense with potential legal consequences.
Administration or Attempted Administration involves providing or facilitating the Use of Prohibited Substances or Methods by others.
This does not include actions by legitimate medical personnel for genuine therapeutic purposes.
Complicity involves assisting, encouraging, or conspiring with someone involved in an ADRV.
This includes aiding or covering up violations or non-compliance with the Code.
Prohibited Association is working with or being associated with an ASP who is under sanction.
This includes obtaining training, advice, or treatment from someone who is sanctioned or convicted related to doping.
Discouraging or Retaliating Against Reporting involves threatening or intimidating someone to prevent them from reporting an ADRV.
It also includes retaliation against anyone who has reported an ADRV or non-compliance with the Code.
